channel.title: Python help
channel.description:
[code]# Programmer: # Date: 02/06/10 # File: Dialogue.py
# This program simulates a dialogue between the computer and a person
def main(): phrases = "Thank You Please Hello Hi nice to meet you" # Add to the phrases in this string literal
print phrases[17:22] # This statement prints a specific segment of characters from the string literal print "What is your name? " # This statement prompts the user to enter their name name = raw_input() # This statement accepts the name the user enters print phrases[23:25] + " " + name + "." # This statement retrieves a specific segment of characters from the string literal, concatenates it with the person's name, and speaks the result print "nice to meet you" " + name + " "."
main() [/code] where do you get the phrases[#:#] from?

item.title: Python help
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

I looked at this and figured out what the numbers were right away. If you have ever done sub strings in any language this makes perfect sense.

print phrases[17:22] #would print "hello"
reallyfuckinggoodphrases = "YOURAFUCKINGHEYDUMBASS"
print reallyfuckinggoodphrases[12:14] # Would print HEY

Read full topic

item.title: Python help
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

if you do [:X] it means 0 to X and if you do [X:] it means from X to the end of the string

Read full topic

item.title: Python help
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

phrases = "Thank You P"
indexes:    0123456789

and so on, 10,11,12. Do you understand now? Just count the characters in the string.

Read full topic

item.title: Python help
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

zammyking111:

wtf how did u get the numbers!?!??!

Have you ever done substring in Java? It’s the same concept.

Read full topic

item.title: Python help
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

zammyking, the [int:int] is stating a range in the string which will be give, for example:

str = "test" print str[0:3] #test print str[0:2] #tes print str[0:1] #te print str[0:0] #t print str[1:3] #est print str[2:3] #st print str[3:3] #t

Do you understand this yet? It’s only been explained 4 or 5 times now.

EDIT: [quote=“zammyking111, post:7, topic:328358”]wtf how did u get the numbers!?!??![/quote]

The numbers are the range of the string to be grabbed, starting at position 0, and ending at len(str)-1

Read full topic

item.title: Python help
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

I know squat about Python, but do you mean that:

phrases = "Wussup noob How are you?"
print phrases[12:24]

Would print “How are you?”

item.title: Python help
item.dc:creator: @zammyking111 zammyking111
item.description:
@zammyking111 wrote:

I still dont understand where you get the #.# from, so like what if i wanted to implement nice to meet you what would i put.

Read full topic

item.title: Python help
item.dc:creator: @eVokki1 Cowie`
item.description:
@eVokki1 wrote:

[quote=“zammyking111, post:1, topic:328358”][code]# Programmer:

Date: 02/06/10

File: Dialogue.py

This program simulates a dialogue between the computer and a person

def main():
phrases = “Thank You Please Hello Hi nice to meet you” # Add to the phrases in this string literal

print phrases[17:22]                        # This statement prints a specific segment of characters from the string literal
print "What is your name? "                 # This statement prompts the user to enter their name
name = raw_input()                          # This statement accepts the name the user enters
print phrases[23:25] + " " + name + "."     # This statement retrieves a specific segment of characters from the string literal, concatenates it with the person's name, and speaks the result
print "nice to meet you" " + name + " "."

main()
[/code]
where do you get the phrases[#:#] from?[/quote]

phrases[#:#] is just a sliced aspect of phrases bro.

Read full topic

item.title: Python help
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

‘phrases’ is defined in the first line of main():
phrases = “Thank You Please Hello Hi nice to meet you”

So, as stated in the comment, print phrases[17:22] will print a part of phrases, I would call it a substring, without running the code, just counting, it should print something similar to:
'Hello ’
I may be off by one one way or the other.

Read full topic

item.title: Python help
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

string[int:int] IIRC is the equivalent of a substring in python.

Read full topic

item.title: Python help
item.dc:creator: @zammyking111 zammyking111
item.description:
@zammyking111 wrote:

[code]# Programmer:

Date: 02/06/10

File: Dialogue.py

This program simulates a dialogue between the computer and a person

def main():
phrases = “Thank You Please Hello Hi nice to meet you” # Add to the phrases in this string literal

print phrases[17:22]                        # This statement prints a specific segment of characters from the string literal
print "What is your name? "                 # This statement prompts the user to enter their name
name = raw_input()                          # This statement accepts the name the user enters
print phrases[23:25] + " " + name + "."     # This statement retrieves a specific segment of characters from the string literal, concatenates it with the person's name, and speaks the result
print "nice to meet you" " + name + " "."

main()
[/code]
where do you get the phrases[#:#] from?

Read full topic
